comments.commentBody: Cowen is correct in pointing out that some 50-somethings and 60-somethings may drop out of the labor force now that they can maintain their health insurance.  Are we to believe something is wrong with that?  Should someone in poor health be forced to work until they expire because that is the only way for them to stay insured?  The ACA gives people a choice by making the individual market for insurance like the group market (with guaranteed issue and community rating).  How many people in the group market would really opt for the way the individual market used to function, with insurance companies free to decline coverage and charge higher premiums based on health status?

The MMPI is actually a very useful tool, and not quite as easy to cheat at as some suggest. There are now clinical tests that can indicate possible future bi-polar disorder in apparently healthy people.  Anyone who is suffering from severe depression, bi-polar disorder, paranoia, or chronic anxiety should be disqualified from flying. The fact that they love to fly, or their right to privacy over medical issues should not trump the right of the public to fly safely on commercial airlines.

This particular tragedy illustrates the dilemma doctors face when dealing with a clearly disabled patient. Mr Lubitz's doctors agreed that he had no business flying, yet under German medical privacy laws they had to worry about being held responsible for a possible violation, meaning civil and possibly even criminal action. Here in the States a doctor is supposed to be required to give such notification to an employer, but there is precious little in the way of shielding from legal action by the patient or his or her family. (Another one of the many reasons why so many physicians suggest a different career to their offspring. Can you blame them?) The general tendency for the system to be hard on doctors, while expecting almost psychic perfection from them, endangers us all, in a number of ways. Not only do people like Mr Lubitz, who'd given ample warning of his disturbance, manage to slip through the cracks, but eventually they might wind up having to draft people into medical school once enough students realise they're headed for a great nightmare of debt and legal danger. Then we can all look forward to VA-style care, Lord help us.
By the way, industry and government might as well give up on those head-games 'psychological' interview questions - you know, favourite colour or what sort of animal you'd wish to be. And they can dump the MMPI (Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory) as well. Just about anyone who's not been living in a cave knows how to cheat on these.

While we study how we contribute to the problem as a society, can we avoid the political pressure to "study the problem" which will only result in the deaths of more innocent people? Guy loved to fly. Lots of guys love to fly. My nephew  loves flying but he didn't have the academic chops to be a pilot, so he became a flight attendant. Now that's a sensible accommodation to his compulsion.

We can't wait for society to change. This is an urgent problem that could recur in a few years or months. I think the lives of hundreds of people do, in this case, have to take priority over a mentally ill person's "right to work". If he were still at Burger King, the odd anxiety outburst or suicidal thought would have no wider repercussion, except perhaps for a batch of substandard burgers or a confrontation with a boss or customer. But pilots, unique among all people, have the power of life and death over hundreds of people and the ability to kill with the flick of a few switches.

I am with those who say there can be zero tolerance for not just drug use among pilots, but medically noted psychological issues. They have to be paid off and dismissed. There will always be healthy candidates to take their place.

It’s easy (and tempting) to look at this tragedy as an isolated incident. It is, perhaps, just one instance that is similar to many instances of deadly antisocial behavior by individuals , be they terrorists, gun wielding mass murders, or now, airline pilots.

We would all like to think that these deadly tendencies are recognizable and predictable. That would reassure us that we could be safe and secure in our daily lives, whether we were in an airplane, a movie theatre, or sending our children off to school.

It’s also natural to look at the individual and place the blame on mental illness. With the proliferation of mass murder scenarios, perhaps there is a contributing factor from our society. The perpetrators seem to often be men under thirty. They seem to have certain ideals that are never able to be met by reality. Their access to lethal weapons allows them to do maximum damage to society as they choose to end their own lives.

The real answers are much more complicated than putting a flight attendant in the cockpit when the captain takes a break. We need to look at how we contribute to the problem as a society before we will find out how to solve the problem. A person intent on taking lives with his own can easily find a way. We need to find out ways to prevent those emotions from becoming as strong and as frequent as they seem to have become.

I struggled with depression on and off from age 18 to 27. during that time period, I attended and graduated from the University of Chicago (with honors) and have been working in the medical field. With the help of therapy and antidepressants, I was able to recover. The vast majority of people with depression are like me- they struggle for a time, but on the whole, contribute to society. Please don't consign us to jobs at Burger King.

The law was never designed to get to 100%. There are no provisions to subsidize the 11 million undocumented immigrants in this country - many of them will remain uninsured. Some older people still can't afford insurance, even with subsidies - they are exempt from tax penalties but will probably remain uninsured. Some healthy people will choose to pay the tax penalty - that is their option.
The CBO has already projected lower health care costs for the future, probably not entirely due to the ACA. Nonetheless, if you're going to blame the ACA for everything that goes wrong, the law at least deserves some credit when things go right.

Also most mentally ill do not experience visual hallucinations, because there are many forms of mental illness, some severe some less severe. But hallucinations are only common in certain cases. Also severely mentally ill persons are (generally) not able to hold full-time demanding, public jobs.

Tom, the critical individual market reforms in the ACA are guaranteed issue for all who want insurance and premium pricing based on community ratings.  Without these reforms, insurance companies will decline to cover the sickest patients and will charge impossible premiums for sicker patients that they do choose to cover.  This will not be altered by selling insurance across state lines or by establishing high-risk pools funded by the state.  If there are other Republican ideas, I haven't heard them.  Oh wait, the ACA is a Republican idea.

@Robert - I agree with the sentiments you express, but they don't allow for any possible way of protecting the privacy of pilots and the safety of passengers. I believe that view is too simple.

Perhaps in retrospect, this crash and MH370 will cause regulators to find a way of accomplishing both objectives -- a way of cutting the Gordian knot. To me, your comment reveals that they should be looking for such a solution. Surely other professions have faced similar challenges.
